table_items.text: TREATMENT OF INFANTS SUFFERING FROM NEONATAL ABSTINENCE SYNDROME (NAS)
CLINICAL GUIDELINES Register No: 09029 Status: Public
Alison Cuthbertson Anita Rao Miss Dutta Dr Agrawal Alison Cuthbertson Paula Hollis Chris Berner Toni Laing Jude Horscraft Emma Neate Sarah Moon Lavina D'Souza Deborah Lepley

Clinical Director for Women's and Children's Division Consultant for Obstetrics and Gynaecology Consultant for Obstetrics and Gynaecology Consultant Paediatrician Head of Midwifery for Women's and Children's Services Lead Midwife Acute In-patient Services Lead Midwife Clinical Governance Lead Nurse for Neonatal Practice Development Midwife Antenatal and Newborn Screening Midwife Specialist Midwife for Guideline and Audit Senior Midwife Postnatal Ward Senior Librarian, Warner Library
Lead Consultant for Obstetrics and Gynaecology
Sharon Pilgrim Advanced Neonatal Nurse practitioner (ANNP)
Policy to be followed by (target staff)
Medical, Midwifery and Neonatal nursing staff
Electronic copies to all appropriate staff on email
Related Trust Policies (to be read in conjunction with)

04071 Standard Infection Prevention 04072 Hand Hygiene 06036 Guideline for Maternity Record Keeping including Documentation in Handheld Records 04064 Safeguarding Children Policy 09111 Management of breast feeding on the Postnatal ward 09110 Management of artificial feeding on the Postnatal ward 04225A Admission to the Neonatal unit

data.text: Document History Review:

table_items.text: Sharon Pilgrim, Hayley Hume and Hannah Chapple

data.text: INDEX
Appendix A - Consequences of drug use in pregnancy Appendix B - Signs and Symptoms observed in the Neonate Appendix C - Referral flow chart
Appendix D - Neonatal Abstinence Scoring System
Appendix E – Drug Management
Appendix F - Supportive therapy
Appendix G – Drug effects on the Breastfeeding Infant
Appendix H – Referral forms (Yellow sheets)
Purpose
To give guidance to all medical, nursing and midwifery staff in identifying infants withdrawing from maternal substance abuse.
(Refer to Appendix B)
Ensure safe resuscitation of the newborn at risk of Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome (NAS)
To enable the early detection of NAS and ensure correct management of these infants.

Standardise and improve patient care to ensure the maintenance of a normal body temperature,  adequate  sleep  patterns,  reduction  of  hyperactivity  and  motor instability and adequate weight gain, using pharmaceutical and non pharmaceutical means
Promote bonding and facilitate good parenting skills
Equality and Diversity
Mid Essex hospitals is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
Background
Low molecular weight and solubility mean that all drugs of abuse reach the fetal circulation by crossing the placenta, causing toxic effects on the fetus.
(Refer to Appendix A)
Main substances are opiates, cocaine and derivatives, amphetamines, and alcohol.
Abnormal neuro-behavioural patterns have also been reported from high doses of caffeine, cigarettes, marijuana and volatile substances.
Patients at Risk
Infants of mothers who have taken drugs from the following list during pregnancy;

table_items.text: Morphine Heroin Methadone Codeine Pentazocine Buprenorphin e Fentanyl
Alcohol Barbiturates Benzodiazepine s Cannabinoids Hypnotics

data.text: Initial Care and Assessment
During labour adequate opiate support should be given, as maternal withdrawal during labour will trigger fetal distress.

The paediatric team should be made aware of the woman's admission and should be present if there are any signs of fetal distress. The woman's ante-natal plan should be identified and followed; if no plan is available the identified midwife for vulnerable women should be contacted.
Naloxone must not be given at delivery as it may precipitate abrupt withdrawal symptoms and induce uncontrollable seizures in the neonate.
Neonatal drug withdrawal is not usually apparent at birth and mothers whose infants are at risk should remain in hospital for  hours following the delivery.
Time of onset is variable
Clinical features may vary depending on:
Type of drugs
Dose ingested and chronicity of use
Timing of the last dose
Gestational age with Term infants having a longer duration of symptoms

Infants born to women with a history of drug misuse can be admitted to the postnatal ward unless legal reasons have been identified for the infant to be separated from the mother in which case the infant should be admitted to the Neonatal Unit (NNU).
(Refer to Appendix C)
There should be a clear plan in the patient's notes as to the social management of the infant following birth (identified by ‘yellow' record sheets).

A full and detailed history of the woman's substance misuse including severity, type of substance and duration of misuse as well as any drug detoxification programmes undertaken should be recorded in the infant's notes. Furthermore, an accurate history should be recorded regarding any other problems during pregnancy and delivery and any resuscitation required.
It is important to consider other diagnosis which may explain the presenting features:
Infection
Hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy
Electrolyte imbalance (Sodium (Na), Calcium (Ca), Magnesium (Mg))
Peri-ventricular haemorrhage

Assessment of the infant's condition should be recorded on the relevant withdrawal chart every 4 hours or when the baby wakes for feeds over a defined period of time relevant to the scoring chart in use.
(Refer to Appendix D)
All assessments and decisions whether to treat NAS must be based on signs and symptoms witnessed over a 12-24 hours period. Action should not be taken on a single assessment.
Infants of women who have used cocaine or substances causing cerebral vaso- constriction in-utero will require a cranial ultrasound prior to discharge.
Management
All infants at risk of NAS should be observed in hospital (with 4-hourly symptom score) for a minimum ofhours

In cases of babies exposed to only single drug SSRI, observation period should be 48 hours. At time of discharge mothers must be handed over the “NAS information leaflet for babies exposed to SSRIs in utero.”
The aim of treatment is to comfort not sedate the infant, supportive non- pharmacological treatment is aimed to minimise disturbance and optimise comfort and is the first line treatment for NAS
(Refer to Appendix F)
Pharmacologic treatment should be commenced following 3 consecutive scores above 8 using the recognised scoring chart.
(Refer to Appendix D)

No study has identified one drug which consistently treats infants for all drug withdrawal. There is some evidence that Opiates reduce seizures, the time to regain birthweight and duration of supportive care. Most infants respond best to a drug from the same group as that which they have been exposed to during pregnancy

Pharmacologic treatment should be started at standard doses and titrated against the response e.g. if significant symptoms persist despite 2-3 consecutive doses the next dose should be adjusted upwards. If the infant is unduly sedated with standard doses, the treatment should be withheld and re-started at a lower dose only if symptoms recur.
(Refer to Appendix E)

Where an infant has been exposed to multiple drugs, or seizure activity is difficult to control on opiates alone, phenobarbitone is the preferred second-line treatment (if morphine alone is insufficient to control symptoms).

Phenobarbitone is also the preferred treatment for non opioid NAS and should be the first line drug for withdrawal from non-opioid central nervous system (CNS) depressants (e.g. benzodiazepines, alcohol, barbiturates) or SSRI/SNRI (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors/ serotonin-noradrenaline reuptake inhibitor) exposure, where the infant is symptomatic. Where Phenobarbitone is used and high doses are required, blood levels should be monitored once steady state concentration is achieved in the plasma.

Once symptoms have been controlled on a stable dose for 48-72 hours, begin to wean treatment. Wean by decreasing the dose not by increasing the dose interval. Decrease dose by 10-15% of the maximum dose that the infant has received, every 48-72 hours.

It takes longer for infants with severe NAS to regain their birth weight and supplementation with high calorie formula may be necessary to provide 150-250 kcal/kg/ day to establish adequate weight gain.
Poor sucking co-ordination may make it difficult to establish oral feeds and supplementary tube or cup feeds may be necessary.

Observe for signs of dehydration if the infant is persistently vomiting or has loose stools. The infant may require urea and electrolytes checking depending on the severity of the symptoms or if they persist beyond  hours.
Withdrawing infants should be nursed in a quiet atmosphere (i.e. reduced lights and noise). For the management of mild symptoms supportive therapy alone may be indicated.
(Refer to Appendix F)
Laboratory Investigations

It is very important to document maternal viral status and offer appropriate vaccination advice as required. Currently hepatitis C infection is not considered a contra-indication to breast-feeding although there is a small theoretical risk of transmission
The most commonly used tests to detect drugs of abuse can only be viewed as screening tests due to the rate of false negative results
Urine is easily obtained but only reflects drugs taken in the last few days prior to delivery and needs to be collected as a st or 2nd sample. Ward testing strips are available on LW and NNU.

Meconium is easily obtained and may be collected for the first 3 days after delivery it reflects the drugs used after the first trimester it has a lower rate of false negatives than urine and identifies drug use over a longer period. However it is harder to analyse and not presently tested locally.
Communication
The parents' information sheet will help the mother's understanding of the particular care her baby may require.
Communication with the families must be consistent and well documented; all entries must be dated and signed in both the maternal and infant health records.
Liaison with the general practitioner (GP), health visitor and social work department should be maintained throughout the infant's stay and a pre-discharge meeting arranged as necessary.
If the woman is already on a drug withdrawal programme, the relevant multidisciplinary teams should be made aware of the delivery.
It is important for parents and family of these infants to know and understand that they will be more irritable and less relaxed than other infants as these symptoms may persist for up to six months.
Breast Feeding
(Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Management of breast feeding in the postnatal period; register No. 09110)
Breast feeding will need to be assessed and agreed on an individual basis as some drugs of misuse will pass into breast milk in quantities large enough to affect the infant.
(Refer to Appendix G)

Unless other contraindications co exist or baby is going for adoption, recommend breast feeding strongly, give the mother all the information she needs to make an informed choice and support her in her choice of feeding.
Antidepressant medications are transferred to breast milk. However, postpartum use of SSRIs is not a contraindication to breastfeeding, and women who choose to breastfeed should be supported.
Discharge

Many of these cases will have been discussed antenatally at an inter-professional meeting and a discharge plan agreed and documented in the maternal notes. If this is not the case a multi-disciplinary team should convene a case conference.
10.2. Where the multi-disciplinary team has identified safe guarding issues a protection planning meeting should be held prior to discharge.
Discharge is at the discretion of the consultant paediatrician in charge of each case and should be considered for a child still receiving medication only if
The dose of medication required to control symptoms is stable or reducing
Parents have demonstrated a capacity to meet all the infants needs
Social services are supportive of early discharge
Follow-up should be arranged as directed by Consultant paediatrician.

Infants should not be discharged home from hospital without a formal written discharge plan that addresses the needs of both the mother and the infant, including referral to drug and alcohol services if appropriate.
Staff and Training
All medical and midwifery staff will be trained in the identification and treatment of infants with Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome.
The correct withdrawal chart will be available on postnatal wards and the neonatal unit. Training on the use of this chart will be given to all midwifery and neonatal staff
. (Refer to Appendix D)
Teaching sessions on the identification of at risk neonate will be available on a monthly basis to all midwifery staff.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection control by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after undertaking any patient contact.
All staff and visitors to the Neonatal unit must gel their hands prior to admission and remove their outside coats.
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.
As a minimum the following specific requirements will be monitored:
Management of the newborn of mothers known to have misused substances in pregnancy
All infants at risk of NAS should be observed in hospital (with 4-hourly symptom score) for a minimum ofhours

In cases of babies exposed to only single drug SSRI, observation period should be 48 hours. At time of discharge mothers must be handed over the “NAS information leaflet for babies exposed to SSRIs in utero.”
For all treated infants there should be correctly completed daily symptom score sheets for the duration of treatment
There should be accurate documentation of maternal drug use including dosage
Maternal viral serology status should be documented
Documentation of all the above
Process for audit, multidisciplinary review of audit results and subsequent monitoring of action plans

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Clinical Governance Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Guideline Management

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.

Quarterly memos are sent to line managers to disseminate to their staff the most currently approved guidelines available via the intranet and clinical guideline folders, located in each designated clinical area.

Guideline monitors have been nominated to each clinical area to ensure a system whereby obsolete guidelines are archived and newly approved guidelines are now downloaded from the intranet and filed appropriately in the guideline folders. ‘Spot checks' are performed on all clinical guidelines quarterly.
Communication

A quarterly ‘maternity newsletter' is issued and available to all staff including an update on the latest ‘guidelines' information such as a list of newly approved guidelines for staff to acknowledge and familiarise themselves with and practice accordingly.
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Focus Magazine that is sent via email to all staff.
Approved guidelines will be disseminated to appropriate staff quarterly via email.

Regular memos are posted on the ‘Risk Management' notice boards in each clinical area to notify staff of the latest revised guidelines and how to access guidelines via the intranet or clinical guideline folders.
References
Ann L Jefferies; Canadian Paediatric Society Fetus and Newborn Committee: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors in pregnancy and infant outcomes. Paediatr Child Health. 2011; 16(9):562
Rachel LC, Paul M, Nehama L, Lea S, Gil K. Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome After In Utero Exposure to Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors in Term Infants. Arch Pediatr Adolesc Med. 2006; 160:173-176
Osborn DA, Jeffrey HE, Cole MJ. Opiate treatment for opiate withdrawal in newborn infants. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2010, Issue  Art. No.:CD002059. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD002059.pub3.
Neonatal Guidelines (2011) Staffordshire, Shropshire and Black Country Newborn Network/
Gomella TL (2009) Neonatology, Management, procedures, On-call problems, Diseases, and Drugs th ed McGraw Hill
BNF for children 2017-2018
Paediatric Formulary Committee (2016). BNF for Children [2017-2018]. London: BMJ Group, Pharmaceutical Press, and RCPCH Publications
Appendix A
Consequences of Drug use in pregnancy
Fetal growth retardation
Increase in fetal loss and premature delivery
Withdrawal symptoms have been seen from days 1-5 in infants of heavy smokers
Infants of smokers are more at risk for sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)
Fetal alcohol syndrome consists of both pre-natal and postnatal growth restriction
Central nervous system involvement
Craniofacial dysmorphic features
Second trimester loss and preterm delivery is associated with excessive alcohol use
Increased rates of abruption, prematurity and growth restriction
Intracranial lesions including haemorrhage and infarction
Adverse pregnancy and neonatal outcomes have been reported
SIDS appears to be more common in cocaine exposed infants – similar to poly
drug users

Infants born to mothers who have used cocaine as well as methadone have a significantly higher first withdrawal score, however it did not significantly affect the need for treatment nor prolong their hospital stay.
Associated with low birth weight and length
Subtle neuro-behavioural abnormalities have been described in infants of heavy users
Withdrawal from maternal opiate use is present in 42-68% of infants of heroin
users and 68-85% of methadone exposed infants
Withdrawal from Heroin typically starts within  hours of birth
Sleep deprivation, disorganisation and fragmentation may be both to postnatal withdrawal or in-utero exposure to opiates
The risk of SIDS is higher
Up to 60% of infants born to women on methadone exhibit withdrawal symptoms.
Usually occurs between 2-7 days after birth
Sub-acute withdrawal may persist for 4-6 months
Can cause hypothermia, hyperbilirubinaemia and CNS depression in the neonate.
Symptoms can be more severe if the mother has been treated with both a benzodiazepine as well as a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSR1)
Symptoms similar to narcotic withdrawal may be present hours or weeks after delivery
Respond well to phenobarbitone therapy
Users of illicit drugs frequently use more than one drug
This increases the risk of abnormal pregnancy outcomes
Symptoms of withdrawal are similar to single drug users but there may be higher scores
The risk of SIDS is greater
Prescribed drugs
The fetus may be exposed to antipsychotic, antidepressants or anticonvulsants
Patients are sometimes prescribed methadone or codeine for the pain of pregnancy over a period of weeks or months
Infants of mothers treated with anti-psychotics, antidepressants may have withdrawal in the neonatal period
Appendix B
Signs and Symptoms observed in the Neonate
These will be related to the substance and timing of use by the patient as follows:
Withdrawal can occur from birth to two weeks of life, but usually appears within 72 hours
If the drugs were taken close to the time of delivery then withdrawal is more likely
The timing of symptoms relates to the type of delivery, the type and amount of maternal anaesthesia, type of drug used by the mother and intrinsic disease in the neonate
Initially the infants may only appear to be restless and then mild tremors occur on handling, which can then progress to spontaneous tremors
Acute symptoms may persist for several weeks but sub-acute symptoms may persist for 4-6months (irritability, sleep problems, hyperactivity, feeding problems and Hypotonia)
These infants may also require special care/intensive care support as they may be preterm or small for dates
Signs are related to altered vagal tone and neurological effects and include:
Hypoactivity/hyperactivity
Apnoea/tachypnoea
Bradycardia/mottling
Hypoxia
Respiratory and metabolic acidosis
Disrupted sleep-wake patterns
Extreme sensitivity to external stimuli
Difficult to console
Regurgitation, vomiting
Poor, weak suck or uncoordinated sucking movement
Persistent and shrill cry
Inability to self-regulate
Yawning
Finger splaying
Sneezing, nasal stuffiness
Temperature instability, sweating
Frantic sucking of fists.
3.0 Central Nervous System Effects
Jittery
Hypersensitive tendon reflexes
Depressed neonatal primitive reflexes (moro or sucking reflexes)
Seizures
4.0 Resulting Symptoms
Lack of rest, sleeps less than 1 hour after feeding
Inability to meet nutritional needs
Fluid and electrolyte imbalances
Repiratory distress
Hypoxic episodes
Infections (generally related to prematurity, prenatal exposure to infection or altered immune status)
Excoriation of nose, knees toes and/or chin
Appendix C

table_items.text: Is there any social input, antenatal plan (yellow pages)?
Inform the emergency social team. Complete alert form
Will have a social care plan. Follow latest plan (in patients' notes/ Labour ward managers office
Butane gas, Opiates with methadone, Methadone, excessive alcohol
Ward on Postnatal, for neonatal abstinence scoring (based on Finnegan 1986) for 72 hours
Paediatrician to be informed when women is in labour and of the social plan
Paediatrician at delivery Inform neonatal unit
Only trained staff to perform NAS observations. If higher than 8 inform Paediatricians

data.text: APPENDIX D
Neonatal Abstinence Scoring System

table_items.text: Excessive high pitched ( or other) cry < 5mins Continuous High pitched (or other) cry > 5 mins
Sleeps < 1 hour after feeding Sleeps <2 hours after feeding Sleeps <3 hours after feeding
Hyperactive Moro Reflex Markedly hyperactive Moro reflex
Mild tremors when disturbed Moderate-severe tremors when disturbed Mild tremors when undisturbed Moderate-severe tremors when undisturbed
Regurgitation (> 2 times during/ post feed ) Projectile vomiting
Watery stools (water ring on nappy round stool)

data.text: Finnegan LP. Neonatal abstinence syndrome: assessment and pharmacotherapy. In: Nelson N, editor. Current therapy in neonatal-perinatal medicine. 2nd ed. Ontario: BC Decker; 1990
Guide to Assessment and Scoring
First score should be recorded approx. 2 hours after birth/ admission.
Initially infants should be scored 4 hourly, except when high scores indicate more frequent scoring
If score at any time is greater or equal to 8, increase to 2 hourly and continue for 24hours from last score of 8 or above
Treat with pharmacotherapy if 3 consecutive scores 8 or greater
Scoring is dynamic. All signs and symptoms observed during the scoring period are included in point total for that period
In a term infant scoring should be performed 30 mins to one hour after a feed, modification may be needed for pre term infant
If pharmacotherapy is not needed, infants should be scored for 48 to 72 hours depending on drug taken by mum

table_items.text: Score 2 if high-pitched at its peak, 3 if high pitched throughout. Infant scored if crying is prolonged, even if not high pitched
This is a scale of increasing severity and an infant should only receive one score from the three levels. Modification will be needed for premature infants

This is a reflex of young infants and occurs when a sudden noise causes the child to stretch out arms and flex the legs. Score if infant exhibits pronounced jitteriness (rhythmic tremors that are symmetrical and involuntary) of the hands during or at the end of a Moro reflex. Score 3 if jitteriness and clonus (repetitive involuntary jerks? Of the hands and/or arms are present during or after the initiation of the reflex
This is a scale of increasing severity and an infant should only receive one score from the four levels. Undisturbed refers to the baby being asleep or at rest in cot

Score if excessive or above-normal muscle tone or tension observed-muscles become stiff or rigid and the infant shows resistance to passive movement. E.g. no head lag when pulled to sitting position, or tight flexion of infants arms and legs (unable to slightly extend when an attempt is made to extend and release the supine infants limbs
Excoriation (skin abrasions resulting from constant rubbing against a surface that is covered e.g. from bed linen. Score only when excoriations first appear/ increase of appear in new area
Score if involuntary muscle contractions which are irregular and exceedingly abrupt (usually single muscle group) are observed

Infant seizures or convulsions are most commonly seen as generalised activity involving tonic extension of all limbs, but sometimes limited to one or both limbs on one side. Unusual limb movement may accompany a seizure e.g. in upper limbs these resemble swimming or rowing. In lower limbs they resemble cycling or pedalling. Other signs can include eye staring lip smacking back arching and fist clenching
Score if sweating is spontaneous and not due to environment or clothing
Score if more than 3yawns in scoring interval
Score if mottling (marbled appearance of pink and pale and white areas is present on chest, trunk, arms or legs
Score if infant sounds congested; mucous may be visible
Score if 3 or more sneezes in scoring interval
Score only if repeated dilation of nostrils is observed without other evidence of lung or airway disease
Respirations are counted for a whole minute. Score only if rate over 60 with no evidence of lung or airway disease. Score 2 is respiration involved recession
score if hyperactive/disorganised sucking, increased rooting reflex or attempts to suck fists or thumbs (more than that of average infant) are observed

Score if demonstrated excessive sucking prior to feed, yet sucks infrequently during feed taking a small amount, and/or demonstrates an uncoordinated sucking reflex (difficulty sucking and swallowing). Premature infants should not be scored for poor feeding if requiring NGT feeds due to immaturity
Score if at least one episode of regurgitation
Score if loose or watery stools are observed. Check nappy after examination if needed

data.text: Finnegan LP. Neonatal abstinence syndrome: assessment and pharmacotherapy. In: Nelson N, editor. Current therapy in neonatal-perinatal medicine. 2nd ed. Ontario: BC Decker; 1990
Drug Management for Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome
Indication: Three consecutive scores of 8 or more on the neonatal drug withdrawal care chart. Morphine
Preparation: Morphine sulphate 10mg in 5ml oral solution (Oromorph)
Uses: Opiate withdrawal
Route: Oral
For convulsions use continuous intravenous infusion (as below)
Dose: Start 40mcg/kg every 4 hours
Increase dose by 10mcg/kg/dose until control is achieved

Weaning: Initially reduce the dose by 10% of the maximum dose until the infant reaches a dose of 40 mcg/kg/dose Then reduce the frequency gradually 4hrly, 6 hourly, 8 hourly,  hourly, once a day over 6 –  days
Discontinue: At a dose of 40mcg/kg once daily
Treatment: As long as baby is symptomatic
Needs 48 hour observation after cessation of drug management.
Side effects: Respiratory depression Half life: 4 hours
Intravenous Infusion

Dilute 2.5mg/kg of morphine sulphate injection to make up 50mls with Dextrose 5% or 10% or N/Saline to give a solution of 0.1mcg/kg/ml commence infusion at 0.1ml/hr (5 mcg/kg) may be increased to 20 mcg/kg to control symptoms or add nd line drug.
Phenobarbitone
Uses: For non opioid withdrawal, Polydrug withdrawal or as an additional drug used
to control severe drug withdrawal with seizures
Route Oral IV for Seizures
Dose: Oral 4mg/kg/day (no loading dose) may need up to 8mg/kg/day. Seizures 20 mg/kg IV loading dose over 20 minutes then maintenance 4mg/kg/day orally
Plasma levels Goal peak plasma levels  –  mg/ml Treatment: As long as baby is symptomatic.
Side Effects: CNS and respiratory depression
Half life: 60 – 180 hours
Appendix E
Clonidine
Uses: For Opioid and non opioid Neonatal Abstinence, May be used as an alternative
or in addition to opioid therapies.
Route: Oral
Dose: Oral 0.5 – 1.5 mcg/kg/day divided into 4 – 6 hourly doses
Increase over 1 – 2 days to target dose
Maintenance dose 3 – 5 mcg/kg/day divided into 4 – 6 hourly doses
Treatment: As long as baby is symptomatic. Side Effects: Hypotension and bradycardia Half life: 44 – 72 hours
Methadone
Uses: For non opioid Neonatal Abstinence, Polydrug withdrawal or as an additional
drug used to control severe drug withdrawal with seizures
Route: Oral
Dose: Start 100 mcg/kg 6 hourly
Reassess 6 hourly
Increase dose by 50mcg/kg/bd until control maintained
Weaning: Over 7 – 10 days
Treatment Control should be maintained on twice day dosing prior to starting to wean dose Needs  hour observation after cessation of drug management.
Side Effects: Sedation Half life: 30 - 35 hours Chlorpromazine
Uses: For non opioid Neonatal Abstinence, Polydrug withdrawal or as an additional
drug used to control severe drug withdrawal with seizures
Route: Oral
Dose: 500mcg – 750mcg 6 hourly.
Reassess daily
To continue on full dosage for 2-4 days prior to weaning
Weaning: Decrease dose 200 mcg/kg/day every rd day
Treatment As long as symptomatic
Needs 48 hour observation after cessation of drug management.
Side Effects: Seizures Half life: 30 - 35 hours
Supportive Therapy

table_items.text: Supportive therapy Minimise environmental and physical stimulation

Positioning e.g. swaddling Dummies Gentle rocking in a vertical position Walking with the infant cuddled closely in a baby sling Administer sedation as indicated. Cluster activities to allow for longer rest periods. Aspirate nasal secretions as needed. Provide soft sheets. Protect infants face from scratching with mittens Consider demand feeding if weight gain is not an issue Consider using preterm formula to establish weight gain. Consider using preterm formula if tolerating feed volume is an issue. Modify the infants environment (noise and light control in severe cases). Bathing may help relax the infant. Provide swinging cradle or baby carrier Soothing music may help.
Rule out other causes of the symptoms
Hypocalcaemia Hypomagnesaemia Hypoglycaemia Hypothermia Sepsis Other causes of convulsions.
Consider urine collection immediately after birth
May be positive for drugs taken in the previous 24 hours.

data.text: Appendix F
Drugs effect on the breastfeeding infants 1.0 Drugs shown to have adverse effects
Amphetamines (become concentrated in human milk)
Cocaine
Heroin
Methylamphetamine
Marijuana
Phenycyclidine
Mothers taking large amounts of benzodiazepines or poly-drug users should be discouraged from breast feeding
Methadone has minimal transfer in human milk
Subutex (buprenorphine) is considered safe for breast feeding but infants must be monitored for signs of withdrawal and feeding problems
Appendix G
Women's & Children's Division
Perinatal Mental Health / Safeguarding / Vulnerable Referral
